column1: Mesopotamia is a name for the area of the Tigris–Euphrates river system
column2: in modern days roughly corresponding to most of Iraq plus Kuwait
column4: and regions along the Turkish-Syrian and Iran–Iraq borders. Widely considered to be one of the cradles of civilization by the Western world
column5: Bronze Age Mesopotamia included Sumer and the Akkadian
column8: all native to the territory of modern-day Iraq. In the Iron Age
column9: it was controlled by the Neo-Assyrian and Neo-Babylonian Empires. The indigenous Sumerians and Akkadians (including Assyrians and Babylonians) dominated Mesopotamia from the beginning of written history (c. 3100 BC) to the fall of Babylon in 539 BC
column10: when it was conquered by the Achaemenid Empire. It fell to Alexander the Great in 332 BC
column12: it became part of the Greek Seleucid Empire.
